_accidents.CI_OtherType: Some process indicators linked to SCADA

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
KOCH NITROGEN COMPANY

Garner Terminal
Garner, Iowa

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
FOR 
THE RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN (RMPlan)


Introduction and Policies

Koch Nitrogen Company (KNC) is committed to managing all operations in a manner that protects the environment and the health and safety of employees, customers, contractors and the public while fully complying with applicable laws and regulations.  KNC?s management philosophy goals are achieved through the implementation of the Environmental Health and Safety Management Systems, by the personal commitments of employees and contractors, and by open communication with employees, customers, neighbors, and regulators.

The purpose of this Risk Management Plan is to provide information about operations at the terminal, programs to prevent accidental chemical releases, emergency response plans in the event an accidental release should occur, the five-year accident history of the terminal and planned changes to improve safety at the terminal.


Stationary Source and Regulated Substance

The Garner Terminal is one of many facilities owned and operated by KNC that supply anhydrous ammonia to the Midwest farming area where it is used primarily as a fertilizer.  At the terminal, anhydrous ammonia is delivered by pipeline and stored until it is loaded on trucks for distribution.  

Anhydrous ammonia is the only toxic substance regulated under the Risk Management Program (RMP) that is present at the Garner Terminal in amounts above threshold quantity.  Propane is stored at the facility; however, it is used strictly as a fuel and as such is exempt from RMP reporting.  The terminal is classified as Program Level 3 under the regulation. 


Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The accidental release prevention and emergency response programs in place at the facility are part of the high standards striven for by KNC.  These high standards include:

?Operating in compliance with required environmental permits and regulatio

ns. 
?Operating and maintaining the assets in such a manner that unintentional releases are minimized.
?Operating and maintaining assets in such a manner that the small releases associated with normal operation and maintenance will be minimized to the extent possible.
?Correcting non-compliance found by regular audits of the facility.


Prevention Program

The Garner Terminal is operating under the guidelines of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) Program.  Ongoing analysis of the potential hazards of the process, detailed training of employees, and emphasis on safety has helped avoid any serious chemical release accidents over the last 5 years.  Part of this program has also involved identifying and taking steps to avoid potential accidental chemical releases.  A few examples of the prevention features implemented at this facility include:

?Minimizing the possibility of overfilling by having level gauges and high pressure alarms on storage tanks and bullets.
?Providing emergency shutdown buttons at the truck loading area that can be activated by KNC personnel or the truck driver in case of an ammonia release.
?Requiring trucks to have a brake interlock system that helps prevent a truck driver from driving away before the loading arm is properly disconnected.
?Providing annual truck loading training to ensure driver safety.
?Preventive maintenance and testing of vessels through the Mechanical Integrity program helps to ensure that structural failures do not occur in process equipment.
?Monitoring the level of liquid ammonia in the bullet on a continuous basis.
?Loading of trucks occurs only when KNC personnel are on site and can monitor activities.


Five-Year Accident History  

The Garner Terminal has had one incident occur during the last five years that is reportable in the five-year accident history maintained under the RMP regulations.  On December 15, 2003, at 4:30 pm, the operator requested ammonia delive

ry from the pipeline.  Ammonia was still being received at approximately 10:41 pm, when the terminal lost power because of high wind in the area.  At the time the power failed, the KNC bullet inlet valve closed as designed.  The valve on the Magellan Pipeline, from which ammonia is received, did not fully close.  Flow continued after the power failure resulting in high pressure in the Garner Terminal piping.  As a result, the relief valve on the discharge line of the cold pump opened (as designed to relieve under high pressure conditions) releasing ammonia into the atmosphere and on to the ground.  Approximately 12,320 pounds of ammonia was released.  One resident was evacuated located 0.25-mile south of the facility, as a precautionary measure.    No other offsite impacts occurred.  There were no onsite injuries or death; however, soil removal and replacement at the facility cost approximately $40,000.  As a result of this incident, some process indicators were tied into the Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition System to monitor the facility from a central control room.


Emergency Response Program

The terminal will continue to conduct emergency response preparedness activities and coordinate any emergency response actions necessary for the Garner Terminal with the Garner Volunteer Fire Department.  Also involved in emergency response for the facility would be the Hancock County Sheriff and, as appropriate, the Mercy Health Center in Mason City, Alliant Electric, and the Iowa State Highway Patrol.  The Garner Terminal Manager is responsible for coordinating the emergency actions.  A specific Emergency Response Plan for the terminal is in place and that plan has been coordinated with local officials.  The Emergency Response Program provides the essential planning for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.


Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Compliance with the RMP Prevention Program, coupled with the Enviro

nmental Health and Safety Management Systems, forms the framework for continuous safety improvement.  Some of the key components of the safety program are:

?The Management of Change provisions ensure that the potential safety and health impacts of any change made to process chemicals, technology, equipment or procedures are considered.
?The Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) provisions serve as a tool to ensure timely evaluation of potential hazards, thereby leading to continual improvements in safety standards.
?The Mechanical Integrity provisions ensure that process equipment and instrumentation are designed, constructed, installed and maintained to minimize the risk of hazardous releases, thereby serving as an integral part of the safety program. 

Specific actions that will be taken in the future to improve the level of safety at the terminal include:
.
?Several additional process indicators will be tied in to the Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition monitoring system for monitoring at a central control room.
?Replacing the existing flare with a new flare that has automated continuous pilots.
?Internal and third party compliance audits will ensure that the level of safety protection at the terminal is periodically evaluated for improvements.
?An ongoing dialogue with the Hancock County Emergency Management Director or his designate will ensure a constant state of readiness to respond to any potential emergencies, as well as a means to implement improvements as the need develops.

All interested citizens or community organizations are encouraged to contact the Hancock County Emergency Management Director for the latest information on emergency response for the county.  The terminal coordinates its response capabilities and personnel with those of the county on an ongoing basis.
